README:
*******************************************************
*PROGRAM FOR SIMULATION OF LATTICE PURE GAUGE THEORIES*
*      AND MEASURE OF POLYAKOV LOOP CORRELATORS       *  
*******************************************************


** ACTION
*****************************************************
The action used is the standard Wilson action, which
for the SU(N) group can be written as the sum of

-beta*(1/N)Re(Tr(paquette))

For the G2 group the convention used is

-beta*Tr(plaquette)

The update is performed by means of heatbath and
overrelaxation updates (for G2 also random gauge 
transformation are used)

The measures are performed by the using a 2 level 
implementation of the multilevel agorithm by 
Luscher & Weisz arXiv:hep-lat/0108014

The anisotropic action follows the conventions in
Klassen Nucl. Phys. B \textbf{533}, 557 (1998)
arXiv:hep-lat/9803010

or, e.g. CP-Pacs collaboration arXiv:hep-lat/0105012

** GAUGE GROUPS
******************************************************

The choice of the gauge group happens at configuration 
time through the macro GAUGEGROUP and, for SU(N), N_c.

The possible choices are
GAUGEGROUP=G2
GAUGEGROUP=Su2
GAUGEGROUP=SuN
GAUGEGROUP=U1
the default one being Su2. For the SuN case the choice
of the number of colors is performed by means of the 
macro N_c (the default value being 2).

As an example, to simulate the SU(5) gauge theory the
program has to be configured through
./configure GAUGEGROUP=SuN N_c=5

For compilers lacking of inter-procedural optimization
it is usually convenient to use also 
--enable-one-file-compilation 
in order to compile just a single big file.

After the configuration, the compilation is performed as
usual by
make


**KNOWN ISSUES
********************************************************

On some systems, configure fails while checking for 
the presence of the SIMD extensions, i.e. in one of
the following lines

checking for x86 cpuid 0x00000001 output... 20655:1100800:29ae3ff:bfebfbff
checking whether mmx is supported... yes
checking whether sse is supported... yes
checking whether sse2 is supported... yes
checking whether sse3 is supported... yes
checking whether ssse3 is supported... yes
checking whether sse4.1 is supported... yes
checking whether sse4.2 is supported... yes
checking whether avx is supported... no

if this happens use
--disable-simd-check


** INPUT PARAMETERS
********************************************************
An example of input file is give by input.in. The format 
of this file is

name_of_the_variable  value_of_the_variable  possible_comments(up to carriage return)

The variables are:

latox, latoy, latoz, latot: the lattice extensions in 
	the x, y, z, and t directions respectively

beta: the beta to be simulated
campione: the number of updates to be performed
thermal: the number of thermalization updates to be
	performed prior to starting the measures
over: number of overrelaxation updates to be performed 
	after each heatbath update
measevery: number of updates between the measures

xi0: bare anisotropy
anis_dir: direction of the anisotropy (0=time)

inizio: starting configuration (0=ordered configuration, 
	1=random configuration, 2=saved configuration)
saveconf: if !=0 the last configuration is written in a 
	file named "configuration"

dist_poly: distance between the Polyakov loops
ml_step1: dimension of the slice for level 1
ml_step2: dimension of the slice for level 2, 
	ml_step1<ml_step2<=latot 
up_level1: number of updates for level 1 
up_level2: number of updates for level 2
slice_repeat: if LONG_SIMULATION is used the total number 
	of updates of level 2 is up_level2*slice_repeat
reduce: used to reduce the use of the RAM (and the 
	statistics) by a a factor of "reduce"

randseed: random seed. If equal to 0 the time is used


** OBSERVABLES
********************************************************

The measured observable is <P(x)P(y)^*> where 
|x-y|=dist_poly. The first line of the output file 
"dati.dat" is 

 latox latoy latoz latot beta

the following ones are given by the observable.

If the configure macro LONG_SIMULATION=yes the measure is
performed across several simulations. In each simulation 
only (possibly part of) the level 2 update is performed.
description: C++ program for the measurement of Polyakov loop correlators in lattice gauge theory using a multilevel algorithm
